required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Informative Letters on the Prescription and Receipt of Schedule II Controlled Substances
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Informative Letters on the Prescription and Receipt of Schedule II Controlled Substances

lead_sponsor.agency: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab

collaborator.agency: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

clinical_study.source: Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab

brief_summary.textblock: Fraud and waste is estimated to cost the American health care system nearly $200 billion each year, and the public Medicare and Medicaid programs about $60 billion each year. This study will evaluate a new method for fighting fraud: mailing informative letters to outlier providers to notify them of their aberrant behavior. These letters are targeted at high prescribers of schedule II controlled substances in Medicare Part D. The investigators will look at the effects of these letters on the behavior of providers and their patients. These effects are of substantial policy interest as they suggest how to best design anti-fraud policies. They are also of academic interest, shedding light on the behavior of physicians and their patients.

primary_outcome.measure: 30-day Equivalent Prescribing of Schedule II Controlled Substances
primary_outcome.description: The prescribing of schedule II controlled substances over the 3 months following the initial sending of the letters. Prescribing is defined as the total "days supply" of schedule II controlled substances attributed to the prescriber, expressed in "30-day equivalents" i.e. divided by 30.

secondary_outcome.measure: 30-day Equivalent Prescribing of Schedule II Controlled Substances
30-day Equivalent Prescribing of Schedule II Controlled Substances
30-day Equivalent Prescribing of Schedule II Controlled Substances
30-day Equivalent Prescribing of Schedule II Controlled Substances

clinical_study.condition: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (U.S.)

arm_group.description: This is the control arm and it involves no contact with the prescriber
This is the treatment arm; prescribers in this arm receive an informative letter (called a comparative billing report or peer activity report)

intervention.description: The intervention is a letter that describes the Schedule II prescribing activity of the individual in comparison to a peer group of similar prescribers. It highlights the fact that the prescriber's activity is highly unlike her peers.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Outlier with respect to the count of schedule II prescription drug events relative to peer group of prescribers in two of the three years 2011, 2012, and 2013
- Outlier with respect to the 30-day equivalent prescriptions of schedule II substances relative to peer group of prescribers in two of the three years 2011, 2012, and 2013
Exclusion Criteria:
- Deceased

link.description: American Economic Association Randomized Controlled Trials Registry Entry

participant_flow.recruitment_details: There was no recruitment in the traditional sense. High prescribers of Schedule II controlled substances were identified in Medicare administrative data using a Tukey outlier method.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Seven of the identified outliers had died by the time of the study and were excluded from the intervention and later analysis.

It highlights the fact that the prescriber's activity is highly unlike her peers.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
